title: A Global Minimum Corporate Tax Is a Loser
sub_head: If Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen was an executive in the private sector, her attempt to collude on international corporate tax rates would likely lead to charges of conspiracy to fix prices.
body:
As long as there are corporate taxes there will be arguments about what is fair, competitive and how to avoid a “race to the bottom” (“U.S. Aims for Global Minimum Corporate Tax Rate,” Page One, April 6). Alas, there is a simple solution: Set the rate at zero.
Corporate taxes support only about 10% of federal receipts, a figure that could be easily covered by raising other taxes. Economists already debate whether corporations truly pay taxes or merely pass them along in an inefficient and, yes, unfair, manner. Clever ploys such as domicile shifting and inversions will be relegated to the scrapheap of corporate history. And if none of this works, well, deficit spending is all the rage anyway; there isn’t the slightest pretense of fiscal discipline anywhere near our nation’s capital.
John Carlson
Boulder, Colo.
The Biden administration’s call for a global minimum corporate tax rate is an American initiative to suppress economic competition among nations. Bottom line, it’s based on the notion that people in government are wise and government structures and bureaucracies are efficient. Who believes that?
